description: From Latin abortiōnem (“miscarriage, abortion”), from aborior (“to miscarry”). Equivalent to abort +‎ -ion. Displaced native Old English ǣwyrp (literally “throwing out, rejection”).

entries.meaning: (medicine) The expulsion from the womb of a foetus or embryo before it is fully developed, with loss of the foetus; either naturally as a spontaneous abortion (now usually called a miscarriage), or deliberately as an induced abortion. [from 16th c.]
examples: Mary decided to have an abortion because she was too young to raise a baby.

entries.meaning: (now rare) An aborted foetus; an abortus. [from 16th c.]
examples: ‘It seems too hairy for an abortion, and too small for a mature birth.’

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A misshapen person or thing; a monstrosity. [from 16th c.]
(figuratively) Failure or abandonment of a project, promise, goal etc. [from 17th c.]
(biology) Arrest of development of any organ, so that it remains an imperfect formation or is absorbed. [from 18th c.]
The cessation of an illness or disease at a very early stage.
